channel.title: Type Inference on Andrew Bancroft
channel.description: Recent content about iOS development with Swift in Type Inference from Andrew Bancroft.

item.title: Expanded Thoughts on Swiftâ€™s Type Inference
item.description:
In my recent op-ed onÂ clean coding in Swift focused on Type Inference, I began by saying,

Quick! Â Tell me! Â What is the Type of theÂ birdDetailsÂ constant in this code example:

let birdDetails = birdDetailsFromStorage()

With no additionalÂ context to glean information from, the correct answer to the question is, “I have absolutely no clueâ€¦â€

But is that concluding assertionÂ true? Â Hmmâ€¦

I’m learning, and as I’ve weighedÂ a recent Twitter conversation and thought on a comment thread that Rob NapierÂ made on the post quoted above, I’m compelled to expand a little on my first post on Type Inference as it relates to clean code in Swift.

SomethingÂ struck me as I readÂ Rob’s comment:Â  WhyÂ wouldn’t I know the Type that would be inferred from what is returned byÂ birdDetailsFromStorage()Â and assigned to birdDetails? Â Presumably, I named the function what I named it intentionally. Â The part I missed, was that ifÂ I had designed well and created aÂ TypeÂ calledÂ BirdDetails (say, a Struct as Rob proposed), then all of a sudden, an inference can be madeÂ by both the compiler and a human that theÂ birdDetailsÂ constant isâ€¦ wellâ€¦ an instance ofÂ BirdDetails. Â Imagine that!

To quote Rob (emphasis added):

Type inference should only be used when the result is unambiguous, but the best solution is to make the result unambiguous.

Bingo. Â The best solution is to make the result unambiguous. Â You and I as code authors are in charge of the clarity or ambiguity of our code â€“ it’s up to us toÂ make the results of our function evaluations unambiguous.

When I named the functionÂ birdDetailsFromStorage(), I heavily implied something about its return Type in the name. Â I even implied it in the name of the constant. Â I was expecting the return Type to be something that encapsulated whatever “bird detailsâ€ are â€“ I just didn’t realize it at the time (although it’s super obvious now)!

The very nameÂ of a thing setsÂ expectations for you and the readers of your code. Â It’s ourÂ job to set ourselvesÂ up for thatÂ expectation to be fulfilled! Â Be predictable with the return Type of your functionsÂ for your own sake. Â AÂ function signature should be such that when you run acrossÂ birdDetailsFromStorage()in some piece ofÂ code, you are able toÂ legitimately expectÂ it to return aÂ BirdDetails. Â 

Using this predictable,Â convention-based approach to give humans the right clues about what the compiler is going to computeÂ a Type to be makesÂ Type Inference a totallyÂ legitimate language feature to embrace for the sake of your code’s clarity and simplicity.

I’ll leave you with a final quote from Rob’s comments:

Don’t go implying that you’re returning one thing when you’re returning another. If you must, then yes, explicit types are your punishment. ğŸ˜€

Thank you Rob for your insight and feedback. Â You can read more of Rob’s work at http://robnapier.net.

You might also enjoy

  • Clean Coding in Swift â€“ Functions
  • Clean Coding in Swift â€“ Type Inference
  • Pick a Delegateâ€¦ Any Delegateâ€¦ On Clean View Controllers in Swift

item.title: Clean Coding in Swift â€“ Type Inference
item.description:
Quick! Â Tell me! Â What is the Type of theÂ birdDetailsconstant in this code example:

1let birdDetails = birdDetailsFromStorage()

With no additionalÂ context to glean information from, the correct answer to the question is, “I have absolutely no clueâ€¦â€ Â Or is it?

“Not fair!â€, you say. Â “In the real world, I’d have the ability to option-click and learn the type from a pop-up tooltip, or learn this information by inspection fromÂ Xcode’s utilities panel.â€

Truth. Â We would. Â Butâ€¦Â should weÂ have to for an example like the one above? Â Could we have helped ourselves out a bit by being explicit about the type of birdDetails?

This was the question I asked myselfÂ as I set out to determine how and when I prefer to explicitly specify the Types of my variables and constants at declaration-time, rather than letting the compilerÂ infer the Type for me.

Type InferenceÂ is powerful andÂ convenient. Â ItÂ enables usÂ to leave off explicit type specificationsÂ when weÂ declare a variable or constant, leaving us with nice, terse, clean-looking code. Â But in reality, for examples like the one posed above, is clean-looking truly “clean codeâ€?

From Apple’s documentation:

Type inference enables a compiler to deduce the type of a particular expression automatically when it compiles your code, simply by examining the values you provide.

The key phrase that stuck out to me was this: Â “Type inference enables aÂ compiler to deduce the type of a particular expressionâ€¦â€. Â Humans are not compilers!

I don’t know about you, but I could use all the help I can get when it comes to figuring out simple things like the Type resulting from an expression. Â Sure, I could rely on the IDE, but in debugging, or in trying to simply read and understand what the intention of my code is when I come back to it sometime later, I want to focus on theÂ code, not on pop-up tool tips or inspector panels.

For instances where deducing the type is not simple for a human to do (and I meanÂ really simple), I’m getting to where I prefer to specify the Type up-front. Â We’re used to doing this in Objective-C, and I even do it in C# when usingÂ varÂ would obscure things. Â When a language gives me the option to be clear about Types, I try to take advantage of that valuable language feature for all but the simplest of situations.

The Simplest of Situations

Let’s think for a moment about this so-calledÂ “simplest of situationsâ€. Â I would define such a situation to be when the Type resulting from an expression canÂ easily, at a glance, be inferred by a human beingÂ without assistance from an IDE. Â It’s all about context here, and for these simplest of situations, I love Type Inference.

Compare the following two lines of code:

1let birdDetails = "Swift"

and

1let birdDetails: String = "Swift"

In the example just presented, typing “: StringÂ â€ to explicitly specify birdDetailsâ€˜ type is superfluous in my opinion (and I prefer not to be repetitively redundant when I can). Â It’s crystal clear that birdDetailsÂ in this example is a String.

However, inÂ situations like the one at the beginning of the article where, by simplyÂ looking,Â I would have to answer,Â “I have no clue what the Type of this isâ€, my preference / proposal for your consideration would be to go ahead and specify the Type at declaration time. Â Consider:

1let birdDetails: (genusSpecies: String, commonName: String) = birdDetailsFromStorage()
2
3
4//... somewhere else in a Swift file far, far away ...
5
6
7func birdDetailsFromStorage() -> (genusSpecies: String, commonName: String) {
8    return ("Apus apus", "Swift")
9}

WhenÂ I’m writing this the first time, I can spend the time looking up the function’s return Type and specify it when I declare my constant. Â It will make my life so much easier down the road.

Don’t stumble over the fact that birdDetailsÂ is aÂ tuple type (String, String). Â The point is that the function could have returnedÂ anything, and it would still have been impossible for me to tell you what the Type of the constant was just by looking, had I not specified it upon its declaration.

Being explicit about the type in the declaration has great potential to immediately help usÂ get ourÂ bearings around a particular set of code when we return to it after any length of time. Â And it seems to me that one of the principal goals of writing clean code is to help ourselvesÂ and ourÂ teams make sense of code quicker so that everyone’s happier and more productive.

Whew. Â That was a long-winded exploration of some things to think about when relying on (or avoiding) Type Inference in your own code. Â Thanks for reading!

Since publishing this op-ed, I’ve expanded my thoughts on Type Inference as it relates to clean coding practices in Swift. Â I highly recommend that this post be read and considered alongside my latest musings,which were heavily influenced by Rob Napier’s comments below.

You might also enjoy

  • Clean Coding in Swift â€“ Functions
  • Expanded Thoughts onÂ Swift's Type Inference
  • Pick a Delegateâ€¦ Any Delegateâ€¦ On Clean View Controllers in Swift
